Line 88: Line 88:
Two unidentified men were killed by the Basij militia during the February 20 protests, each respectively in the [[Vanak]] and [[Valiasr Street|Vali Asr]] squares.<ref name="Wall Street"/>
Two unidentified men were killed by the Basij militia during the February 20 protests, each respectively in the [[Vanak]] and [[Valiasr Street|Vali Asr]] squares.<ref name="Wall Street"/>
â
==Response==
+
== Domestic responses ==
â
===Domestic===
 
{{main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Iranian protests}}
{{main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Iranian protests}}
All forms of Iranian media were banned from covering the protests, though the demonstrators were still able to release information by utilizing social media like [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].<ref name="AFP"/> In addition, foreign media was banned from covering the events.<ref name="Forbes"/> Beginning February 10th, in anticipation of protests in Iran, the Iranian government began censoring "pro-opposition websites and other electronic media". The keyword "Bahman", which is the current month in the Persian calender, was also "added to the list of blocked keywords for messages on mobile phones in an attempt to reduce calls for protests on a specific day." This censorship has resulted in slowed internet connection speed in many major cities of Iran.<ref>{{cite news |title=Faced with protests, Iran strengthens censorship |author= |url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/international/faced-with-protests-iran-strengthens-censorship-25-ncx-20110215 |newspaper=[[WFXT]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Tries Internet Censorship, Execution As Protesters Demand Democracy |author=Nitasha Tiku |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/02/iran_tries_internet_censorship.html |newspaper=[[New York Magazine]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
All forms of Iranian media were banned from covering the protests, though the demonstrators were still able to release information by utilizing social media like [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].<ref name="AFP"/> In addition, foreign media was banned from covering the events.<ref name="Forbes"/> Beginning February 10th, in anticipation of protests in Iran, the Iranian government began censoring "pro-opposition websites and other electronic media". The keyword "Bahman", which is the current month in the Persian calender, was also "added to the list of blocked keywords for messages on mobile phones in an attempt to reduce calls for protests on a specific day." This censorship has resulted in slowed internet connection speed in many major cities of Iran.<ref>{{cite news |title=Faced with protests, Iran strengthens censorship |author= |url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/international/faced-with-protests-iran-strengthens-censorship-25-ncx-20110215 |newspaper=[[WFXT]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Tries Internet Censorship, Execution As Protesters Demand Democracy |author=Nitasha Tiku |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/02/iran_tries_internet_censorship.html |newspaper=[[New York Magazine]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
Line 98: Line 98:
[[President of Iran|Iranian President]] [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] released a statement saying, "It is clear the Iranian nation has enemies because it is a nation that wants to shine, conquer peaks and change [its international] relations...Of course, there is a lot of hostility against the government. But they knew that they would get nowhere....[the organizers of the protests] just wanted to tarnish the Iranian nation's brilliance...It is a shining sun. They threw some dust towards the sun... but the dust will return to their eyes."<ref name="Nowhere">{{cite news |title=Iran protests 'going nowhere', says Mahmoud Ahmadinejad |author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12475824 |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
[[President of Iran|Iranian President]] [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] released a statement saying, "It is clear the Iranian nation has enemies because it is a nation that wants to shine, conquer peaks and change [its international] relations...Of course, there is a lot of hostility against the government. But they knew that they would get nowhere....[the organizers of the protests] just wanted to tarnish the Iranian nation's brilliance...It is a shining sun. They threw some dust towards the sun... but the dust will return to their eyes."<ref name="Nowhere">{{cite news |title=Iran protests 'going nowhere', says Mahmoud Ahmadinejad |author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12475824 |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
â
====Calls for executions====
+
=== Calls for executions ===
On 15 February Iran's state-run Press TV reported that members of the Iranian parliament had called for the execution of two opposition leaders for inciting demonstrations on the previous day.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iranian lawmakers condemn protests; call for execution of leaders|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/15/iran.protests/index.html?hpt=T1 |newspaper=CNN|date=15 February 2011|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iranian Lawmakers Call for Death of Opposition Leaders|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16iran.html?_r=1&src=mv |newspaper=New York Times|date=15 February 2011|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> 221 of the MPs present at the Iranian parliament signed a statement that said, "Mehdi Karroubi and Mir Hossein Mousavi are corrupts on earth and should be tried. We believe the people have lost their patience and demand capital punishment." The term "corrupts on earth" is a specific Iranian charge also known as [[moharebeh]] that carries the [[death penalty]]. After signing the statement, the signatories gathered in the center of the chamber <ref name="fozoole mahaleh 02">{{cite news |title=ÙÙØ§ÛÙØ¯Ú¯Ø§Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ø Ø¨Ø³ÛØ¬ÛØ Ù¾Ø§Ø³Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø ÙÙÚ©Ø±Ø§Ù ÙÙÛ ÙÙÛØ­Ø Ù ÙØ²Ø¯ÙØ± Ù Ø®ÛØ§ÙØªÚ©Ø§Ø± Ø¨Ù ÙÙØª Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù |author=Sohraab Arjang |url=http://www.fozoolemahaleh.com/2011/02/16/ÙÙØ§ÛÙØ¯Ú¯Ø§Ù-ÙØ¬ÙØ³-Ø®ÛØ§ÙØªÚ©Ø§Ø±-Ø¨Ù-ÙÙØª-Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2011}}</ref> chanting, "Death to Mousavi, death to Karroubi".<ref name="Nowhere"/><ref name="Post">{{cite news |title=Iran opposition leader ready to 'pay any price' |author=Ali Akbar Dareini |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/16/AR2011021601914.html |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
On 15 February Iran's state-run Press TV reported that members of the Iranian parliament had called for the execution of two opposition leaders for inciting demonstrations on the previous day.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iranian lawmakers condemn protests; call for execution of leaders|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/15/iran.protests/index.html?hpt=T1 |newspaper=CNN|date=15 February 2011|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iranian Lawmakers Call for Death of Opposition Leaders|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16iran.html?_r=1&src=mv |newspaper=New York Times|date=15 February 2011|accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> 221 of the MPs present at the Iranian parliament signed a statement that said, "Mehdi Karroubi and Mir Hossein Mousavi are corrupts on earth and should be tried. We believe the people have lost their patience and demand capital punishment." The term "corrupts on earth" is a specific Iranian charge also known as [[moharebeh]] that carries the [[death penalty]]. After signing the statement, the signatories gathered in the center of the chamber <ref name="fozoole mahaleh 02">{{cite news |title=ÙÙØ§ÛÙØ¯Ú¯Ø§Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ø Ø¨Ø³ÛØ¬ÛØ Ù¾Ø§Ø³Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø ÙÙÚ©Ø±Ø§Ù ÙÙÛ ÙÙÛØ­Ø Ù ÙØ²Ø¯ÙØ± Ù Ø®ÛØ§ÙØªÚ©Ø§Ø± Ø¨Ù ÙÙØª Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù |author=Sohraab Arjang |url=http://www.fozoolemahaleh.com/2011/02/16/ÙÙØ§ÛÙØ¯Ú¯Ø§Ù-ÙØ¬ÙØ³-Ø®ÛØ§ÙØªÚ©Ø§Ø±-Ø¨Ù-ÙÙØª-Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2011}}</ref> chanting, "Death to Mousavi, death to Karroubi".<ref name="Nowhere"/><ref name="Post">{{cite news |title=Iran opposition leader ready to 'pay any price' |author=Ali Akbar Dareini |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/16/AR2011021601914.html |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
Line 107: Line 107:
Pro-government clerics began calling for the execution of ex-president [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] on February 16, as he had become increasingly aligned with the Green Movement since the 2009 election protests<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
Pro-government clerics began calling for the execution of ex-president [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] on February 16, as he had become increasingly aligned with the Green Movement since the 2009 election protests<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
â
====Clerics call for "anger" rally====
+
=== Clerics call for "anger" rally ===
The Islamic Propagation Coordination Council called for a rally on February 18, 2011, in order to "show anger at what it calls the 'crimes' of 'seditionist' leaders and their rebel allies." As a result, before and after Friday prayer, thousands of pro-government demonstrators poured to the streets of major cities to demonstrate their support and demand prosecution of Mousavi, Karroubi and Khatami. <ref name="VOA">{{cite news |title=Iranian Govt. Calls for Friday Rally to Show 'Hatred' for Opposition |author= |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Clashes-Breakout-at-Memorial-for-Protest-Victim-in-Iran-116298439.html |newspaper=[[Voice of America]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
The Islamic Propagation Coordination Council called for a rally on February 18, 2011, in order to "show anger at what it calls the 'crimes' of 'seditionist' leaders and their rebel allies." As a result, before and after Friday prayer, thousands of pro-government demonstrators poured to the streets of major cities to demonstrate their support and demand prosecution of Mousavi, Karroubi and Khatami. <ref name="VOA">{{cite news |title=Iranian Govt. Calls for Friday Rally to Show 'Hatred' for Opposition |author= |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Clashes-Breakout-at-Memorial-for-Protest-Victim-in-Iran-116298439.html |newspaper=[[Voice of America]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
â
=== International ===
+
=== International reactions ===
{{Main|International reactions to 2011 Iranian protests}}
{{Main|International reactions to 2011 Iranian protests}}
â
====Non-governmental organizations====
+
=== Non-governmental organizations ===
The police crackdown on protesters led [[Amnesty International]] to denounce Iranian authorities. They released a statement saying, "Iranians have a right to gather to peacefully express their support for the people of Egypt and Tunisia."<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protest Crackdown Condemned |author= |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/iran-protest-crackdown-condemned-2011-02-14 |newspaper=[[Amnesty International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
The police crackdown on protesters led [[Amnesty International]] to denounce Iranian authorities. They released a statement saying, "Iranians have a right to gather to peacefully express their support for the people of Egypt and Tunisia."<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protest Crackdown Condemned |author= |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/iran-protest-crackdown-condemned-2011-02-14 |newspaper=[[Amnesty International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
â
====Canada====
+
=== Canada ===
[[Lawrence Cannon]], [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Foreign Minister]], released a statement saying, "Canada is deeply concerned by the violence perpetrated by Iranian authorities against peaceful protestors in Tehran. The hypocrisy of Iranian authorities' calls for democracy in Egypt and suppression of the same demands in Iran is deeply disturbing."<ref>{{cite news |title=Canada accuses Iran of 'hypocrisy' |author= |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jmWVtTUpYgbnHOsCpQzn-l4q5jcQ?docId=CNG.68fd3cfd2282503c7edd2edbea786e20.841 |newspaper=AFP |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
[[Lawrence Cannon]], [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Foreign Minister]], released a statement saying, "Canada is deeply concerned by the violence perpetrated by Iranian authorities against peaceful protestors in Tehran. The hypocrisy of Iranian authorities' calls for democracy in Egypt and suppression of the same demands in Iran is deeply disturbing."<ref>{{cite news |title=Canada accuses Iran of 'hypocrisy' |author= |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jmWVtTUpYgbnHOsCpQzn-l4q5jcQ?docId=CNG.68fd3cfd2282503c7edd2edbea786e20.841 |newspaper=AFP |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
â
====United Kingdom====
+
=== United Kingdom ===
[[William Hague]], the [[Foreign Secretary]] for [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland|the U.K.]], commented, "I have seen reports today of peaceful demonstrators being assaulted by Iranian security forces. President Ahmadinejad last Friday told the Egyptian people that they had the right to express their own views about their country. I call on the Iranian authorities to allow their own people the same right and to ensure that the security authorities exercise restraint."<ref name="Fox">{{cite news |title=Mideast Revolution Sparks Pro-Democracy Protest in Iran |author=Amy Kellogg |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/14/mideast-revolution-sparks-pro-democracy-protest-iran/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
[[William Hague]], the [[Foreign Secretary]] for [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland|the U.K.]], commented, "I have seen reports today of peaceful demonstrators being assaulted by Iranian security forces. President Ahmadinejad last Friday told the Egyptian people that they had the right to express their own views about their country. I call on the Iranian authorities to allow their own people the same right and to ensure that the security authorities exercise restraint."<ref name="Fox">{{cite news |title=Mideast Revolution Sparks Pro-Democracy Protest in Iran |author=Amy Kellogg |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/14/mideast-revolution-sparks-pro-democracy-protest-iran/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Tony Blair]], former British [[Prime Minister]], stated "I think it's very important that we stand up now for those people who want to protest for freedom and proper democratic elections in Iran." He added, "I think [a change in Iran's government] would be possibly the single most dramatic change in the whole of the region because you would then have Iran playing a constructive part. You would have Iran not trying to destabilize other countries in the region, and arming militia-type groups."<ref name="Fox"/>
[[Tony Blair]], former British [[Prime Minister]], stated "I think it's very important that we stand up now for those people who want to protest for freedom and proper democratic elections in Iran." He added, "I think [a change in Iran's government] would be possibly the single most dramatic change in the whole of the region because you would then have Iran playing a constructive part. You would have Iran not trying to destabilize other countries in the region, and arming militia-type groups."<ref name="Fox"/>
â
====United States====
+
=== United States ===
In an advance response, the [[US State Department]] set up a [[Persian language|Persian]] language [http://twitter.com/USAdarFarsi Twitter feed] the day before, in order to allow easier communication by Iran's internet users with the outside world.<ref name="UPI"/> The Department's first tweet on the feed announced, "US State Dept recognizes historic role of social media among Iranians. We want to join in your conversations".<ref name="CNN"/>
In an advance response, the [[US State Department]] set up a [[Persian language|Persian]] language [http://twitter.com/USAdarFarsi Twitter feed] the day before, in order to allow easier communication by Iran's internet users with the outside world.<ref name="UPI"/> The Department's first tweet on the feed announced, "US State Dept recognizes historic role of social media among Iranians. We want to join in your conversations".<ref name="CNN"/>
